newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asia Product Swaps - Mar fuel down on prompt offers.
newsitem.headline: Asia Product Swaps - Mar fuel down on prompt offers.

text.p: The front month March fuel oil swaps were down at midday on Tuesday on fears that there is no longer any physical buying support for prompt cargoes, traders said.
"The market slipped after no buyers came out to support the market yesterday in the face of a low offer," one trader said.

March fuel oil swaps were quoted at $96.00/$97.50.00 per tonne, down from Monday's $98.25/$99.25. But April swaps were down slightly in reaction to the sharp overnight crude losses at $94.50/$96.00 against Friday's $95.50/$96.50 per tonne.
On Monday, a trader offered 20,000 tonnes of fuel oil loading April 5-9 at $99.00 per tonne free-on-board Singapore, down $2.00 per tonne from Friday's offered level.
Physical fuel oil traded on Thursday at $101.50 per tonne but the trader who bought the cargo was no longer in the market to buy.
Overnight, April Brent crude lost a hefty 58 cents to close at $19.28 per barrel while March gas oil was down $2.00 per tonne to end at $167.00.
Despite these large falls, gas oil swaps were down only slightly in quiet trade.
March gas oil were last quoted at $25.90/$26.15 per barrel, down from Monday's $26.10/$26.30, brokers said. April was quoted at $24.50/$24.70, down 10 cents from Monday.
Brokers said April swaps traded earlier in the day at $24.50 per barrel.
April swaps traded earlier in the day at $24.80 per barrel.
Traders said the market's strength was primarily due to expectations of continued buying from a local trader who had since the start of last week bought prompt several cargoes.

The local trader had on Monday bought two cargoes totalling 370,000-barrels at $27.00 and $27.30 per barrel fob Singapore. This is on top of the 890,000-barrels the trader bought last week in five cargoes.
